title_sort: james s. stillwell to walt whitman, 2 september 1864
title: James S. Stillwell to Walt Whitman, 2 September 1864
text: Dear FriendI take this time to write to you to let you know how I am I am well at presant[present] my wound is most heald[held] up and I hope that these few lines will find you wellI reseived[received] your letter and was glad to here from you but I was Sorry to here that you was Sick but I hope that you are well again before this time, I am home now I came home the (22) of august I only got twenty (20) days furlough So I havent[haven't] very long to Stay home it will be up the tenth (10) of this month I am A goin[going] to new york A tuesday[Tuesday] the Six (6) and if I have time I will come an See you I expected to have come home before or I should of wrote to you before this mother Send her best respects to you and would be glad to See you and So would all the rest I Shall try and get transfered[transferred] to new york before I go back to chestnut Hill, I will Send this to Washington and if you a[i]nt there they can Send it back to you fore I dont[don't] no how to derrect[direct] it to you to BrooklynSo no more at preseant[present] good by from your friendJames S. Stilwelldirect your letter to Commack Long Island N.Y. fore if I ant here mother will get it James S. Stillwell to Walt Whitman, 2 September 1864
